title: Veterinary Diagnosis: Emergency Surgery
hint: A life-threatening emergency requiring immediate surgery

clues.text: Sudden onset of severe abdominal distension
clues.explanation: The stomach rapidly fills with gas and fluid, expanding dramatically within minutes to hours, creating visible abdominal swelling.

clues.text: Unproductive retching - trying to vomit but nothing comes up
clues.explanation: When the stomach twists (volvulus), the esophageal opening is blocked, preventing the dog from vomiting or belching despite severe nausea.
The condition causes severe pain and anxiety, with affected dogs unable to find a comfortable position.

clues.text: Weak pulse and pale gums indicating shock
clues.explanation: Gastric torsion compresses major blood vessels, causing circulatory shock with weak peripheral pulses and poor tissue perfusion.

clues.text: Most common in large, deep-chested breeds like Great Danes
clues.explanation: Deep-chested dogs have greater space for stomach movement. Breeds like Great Danes, German Shepherds, and Standard Poodles are at highest risk.

clues.text: X-ray shows 'double bubble' or compartmentalized stomach
clues.explanation: Radiographs reveal a classic appearance of a gas-filled, twisted stomach with the pylorus displaced, creating distinct compartments.
